questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=R_2=R_3=R_4=1\,\text{k}\Omega$$ and $$E=10\,\text{V}$$, the electric current $$i$$ supplied by the battery and the power dissipated in $$R_4$$ are respectively:
questions.E: Let $$R=R_1=R_2=R_3=R_4=1\,\text{k}\Omega$$, the equivalent resistance between points $$a$$ and $$b$$ is $$\\ R_e=R_4+R_{123}\\$$ where $$\\ \frac{1}{R_{123}}=\frac{1}{R_1}+\frac{1}{R_2}+\frac{1}{R_3}=\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{R}=\frac{3}{R}\therefore R_{123}=\frac{R}{3}\\$$Thus, $$\\ R_e=R_4+\frac{R}{3}=R+\frac{R}{3}=\frac{4}{3}R\\$$ By Ohm's law, the electric current is $$\\i=\frac{E}{R_e}=\frac{E}{\frac{4}{3}R}=\frac{3E}{4R}=\frac{3\times (10\,\text{V})}{4\times(1\,\text{k}\Omega)}=\frac{15}{2}\,\text{mA}\\$$The power dissipated in $$R_4$$ is $$\\ P=R_4i^2= (1\,\text{k}\Omega)(\frac{15}{2}\,\text{mA})^2=\frac{225}{4}\,\text{mW}$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=R_3=4\,\text{k}\Omega$$, $$R_2=2\,\text{k}\Omega$$ and the ammeter reading is 3 mA, the values of $$i_2$$ and $$i_3$$ are respectively:
questions.E: The equivalent resistance between points $$a$$ and $$b$$ is $$\\ R_e=\frac{R_2R_3}{R_2+R_3}=\frac{(2\,\text{k}\Omega)(4\,\text{k}\Omega)}{2\,\text{k}\Omega+4\,\text{k}\Omega}=\frac{4}{3}\,\text{k}\Omega \\$$ Thus, the potencial difference between $$a$$ and $$b$$ is $$V_{ab}=R_e\times i=(\frac{4}{3}\,\text{k}\Omega) \times (3\,\text{mA})=4\,\text{V}\\ $$ Applying Ohm's law we have: $$\\ i_2=\frac{V_{ab}}{R_2}=\frac{4\,\text{V}}{2\,\text{k}\Omega}=2\,\text{mA}  \\ i_3=\frac{V_{ab}}{R_3}=\frac{4\,\text{V}}{4\,\text{k}\Omega}=1\,\text{mA}$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$E_1=E_2=2\,\text{V}$$, $$r_1=1\,\Omega$$, $$r_2=R=2\,\Omega$$. If the power dissipated in $$P_{r_2}=0.125\,\text{W}$$ and $$P_{R}=1.125\,\text{W}$$, the power dissipated in $$r_1$$ is:
questions.E: The power dissipated in a resistor with resistance $$r$$ and electric current $$i$$ is $$P=ri^2$$. Thus, the currents in $$r_2$$ and $$R$$ are $$\\ i_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{P_{r_2}}{r_2}}= \sqrt{\frac{0.125\,\text{W}}{2\,\Omega}}=0.25\,\text{A}\\ I=\sqrt{\frac{P_R}{R}}= \sqrt{\frac{1.125\,\text{W}}{2\,\Omega}}=0.75\,\text{A}\\$$ Applying Kirchhoff's first rule to node a: $$\\ i_1=I-i_2=0.75\,\text{A}-0.25\,\text{A}=0.5\,\text{A}\\$$Thus, the power dissipated in $$r_1$$ is $$\\ P_{r_1}=r_1i_1^2=(1\,\Omega)(0.5\,\text{A})^2=0.25\,\text{W} $$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$E_1=E_2=2\,\text{V}$$, $$R=2\,\Omega$$. If voltage across ab is $$1.5\,\text{V}$$ and $$i_1=0.5\,\text{A}$$, the values of $$r_1$$ and $$r_2$$ are:
questions.E: The voltage across ab is given by: $$\\ V_{ab}=E_1-r_1i_1=1.5\,\text{V}\quad \color{red}(1)\color{black}\\$$or$$\\ V_{ab}=E_2-r_2i_2=1.5\,\text{V}\quad \color{red}(2)\color{black}\\$$ From  eq(1): $$\\ r_1=\frac{V_{ab}-E_1}{-i_1}=\frac{1.5\,\text{V}-2\,\text{V}}{-0.5\,\text{A}}=1\,\Omega\\$$ Also notice that $$\\ I=\frac{V_{ab}}{R}=\frac{1.5\,\text{V}}{2\,\Omega}=0.75\,\text{A}\\$$ Using Kirchhoff's first rule to node a $$\\ i_2=I-i_1=0.75\,\text{A}-0.5\,\text{A}=0.25\,\text{A}\\$$ Thus, from eq(2) $$\\ r_2=\frac{V_{ab}-E_2}{-i_2}=\frac{1.5\,\text{V}-2\,\text{V}}{-0.25\,\text{A}}=2\,\Omega$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_2=20\,\Omega$$, $$R_3=10\,\Omega$$ and  $$i_2=0.3\,\text{A}$$. If the ammeter reading is $$1.8\,\text{A}$$, the value of $$R_1$$ is:
questions.E: Using Ohm's law, the voltage across $$R_2$$ is given by: $$\\V_2=R_2i_2=20\,\Omega\times 0.3\,\text{A}=6\,\text{V}\\$$So, the current through $$R_3$$ is $$\\ i_3=\frac{V_2}{R_3}=\frac{6\,\text{V}}{10\,\Omega}=0.6\,\text{A}\\$$ From Kirchhoff's first rule applied to node a $$\\ i_1=I-i_2-i_3=1.8\,\text{A}-0.3\,\text{A}-0.6\,\text{A}=0.9\,\text{A}\\$$Again, applying Ohm's law to $$R_1$$ we have $$\\R_1=\frac{V_2}{i_1}=\frac{6\,\text{V}}{0.9\,\text{A}}=6.7\,\Omega$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown  $$R_1=20\,\Omega$$, $$R_2=10\,\Omega$$, $$R_3=15\,\Omega$$. If the power dissipated in $$R_3$$ is $$\frac{1}{8}\,\text{W}$$ the ammeter reading is:
questions.E: The power dissipated in a resistor with resistance $$r$$ and electric current $$i$$ is $$P=ri^2\\$$So, the electric current through $$R_3$$ is $$\\ i_3=\sqrt{\frac{P_{R_3}}{R_3}}=\sqrt{\frac{\frac{1}{8}\,\text{W}}{15\,\Omega}}=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}\\$$Using Ohm's law, the voltage across $$R_3$$ is $$\\ V_3=R_3i_3=(15\,\Omega)(\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A})=\frac{15}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{V}\\$$On the other hand, voltages across $$R_1$$, $$R_2$$ and $$R_3$$ are equal as the resistors are in parallel, i.e., $$V_1=V_2=V_3\\$$ Hence $$\\ i_1=\frac{V_3}{R_1}=\frac{\frac{15}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{V}}{20\,\Omega}=\frac{3}{8}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}\\i_2=\frac{V_3}{R_2}=\frac{\frac{15}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{V}}{10\,\Omega}=\frac{3}{4}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}\\$$Applying Kirchhoff's first rule to node b:$$\\i=i_1+i_2+i_3=\frac{3}{8}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}+\frac{3}{4}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}+\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}=\frac{13}{8}\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}\,\text{A}$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown  $$E=100\,\text{V}$$, $$R_3=20\,\Omega$$, $$R_4=25\,\Omega$$, voltage across $$R_1$$ is $$V_{R_1}=40\,\text{V}$$ e $$I=2\,\text{A}$$. The value of $$R_2$$ is:
questions.E: Using Ohm's law, the volatge across $$R_4$$ is $$V_{R_4}=R_4I=(25\,\Omega)(2\,\text{A})=50\,\text{V}\\$$Applying Applying Kirchhoff's second rule to the upper loop  $$\\ V_{R_3}=E-V_{R_1}-V_{R_4}= 100\,\text{V}-40\,\text{V}-50\,\text{V}=30\,\text{V} \\$$Since $$R_2$$ and $$R_3$$ are en parallel $$V_{R_2}=V_{R_3}\\$$ Applying Ohm's law to $$R_3\\ i_3=\frac{V_{R_2}}{R_3}=\frac{30\,\text{V}}{20\,\Omega}=1.5\,\text{A}\\$$Applying Kirchhoff's first rule to node a:$$\\i_2=I-i_3=2\,\text{A}-1.5\,\text{A}=0.5\,\text{A}\\$$Applying Ohm≈õ law to $$R_2\\ R_2=\frac{V_{R_2}}{i_2}=\frac{30\,\text{V}}{0.5\,\text{A}}=60\,\Omega$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=400\,\Omega$$, $$R=600\,\Omega$$, the battery has an e.m.f $$E=100\,\text{V}$$ and its internal resistance is negligible. The ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and the internal resistance of the voltmeter is $$R_V=1000\,\Omega$$ The readings of the voltmeter and ammeter are respectively:
questions.E: Since the ammeter is ideal (zero internal resistance) we can remove it from the circuit. On the other hand, the voltmeter has an internal resistance, it can be replaced by $$R_V$$ which is in parallel with the battery. So the voltmeter reading is $$100\,\text{V}.\\$$ Apllying Ohm's law, the current through $$R_1$$ and $$R_2\\I_{12}=\frac{E}{R_1+R_2}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{100\,\Omega+600\,\Omega}=0.1\,\text{A}\\$$The current through the voltmeter is $$\\ I_V=\frac{E}{R_V}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{1000\,\Omega}=0.1\,\text{A}\\$$ Thus, from Kirchhoff's first rule $$\\ I=I_{12}+I_V=0.1\,\text{A}+0.1\,\text{A}=0.2\,\text{A}$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=400\,\Omega$$, $$R=600\,\Omega$$, the battery has an e.m.f $$E=100\,\text{V}$$ and its internal resistance is negligible. The ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and the internal resistance of the voltmeter is $$R_V=1000\,\Omega$$ The readings of the voltmeter and ammeter are respectively:
questions.E: Since the ammeter is ideal (zero internal resistance) we can remove it from the circuit. On the other hand, the voltmeter has an internal resistance, it can be replaced by $$R_V$$. Since $$R_1$$, $$R_2$$ and $$R_V$$ are in parallel their voltages are equal to $$E=100\,\text{V}$$ and their currents are $$\\ I_1=\frac{E}{R_1}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{400\,\Omega}=\frac{1}{4}\,\text{A}\\ I_2=\frac{E}{R_1}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{600\,\Omega}=\frac{1}{6}\,\text{A}\\ I_V=\frac{E}{R_V}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{1000\,\Omega}=\frac{1}{10}\,\text{A}\\ $$Using Kirchhoff's first rule: $$\\ I=I_1+I_2+I_V=\frac{1}{4}\,\text{A}+\frac{1}{6}\,\text{A}+\frac{1}{10}\,\text{A}=\frac{31}{60}\,\text{A}$$.

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=400\,\Omega$$, $$R=600\,\Omega$$, the battery has an e.m.f $$E=100\,\text{V}$$ and its internal resistance is negligible. The ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and the internal resistance of the voltmeter is $$R_V=1000\,\Omega$$ The readings of the voltmeter and ammeter are respectively:
questions.E: Since the ammeter is ideal (zero internal resistance) we can remove it from the circuit. On the other hand, the voltmeter has an internal resistance, it can be replaced by $$R_V$$. The equivalent resistance between the battery terminals is $$\\ R=R_1+R_{2v}\\$$where $$R_{2V}=\frac{R_2R_V}{R_2+R_V}=\frac{(600\,\Omega)(1000\,\Omega)}{600\,\Omega+1000\,\Omega}=375\,\Omega\\$$The current supplied by the battery is $$\\ I=\frac{E}{R_1+R_{2V}}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{400\,\Omega+375\,\Omega}=\frac{4}{31}\,\text{A}\\$$The voltmeter reading is $$\\V=R_{2V}I=(375\,\Omega)(\frac{4}{31}\,\text{A})=\frac{1500}{31}\,\text{V}=48\frac{12}{31}\,\text{V}$$

questions.Q: In the circuit shown $$R_1=400\,\Omega$$, $$R=600\,\Omega$$, the battery has an e.m.f $$E=100\,\text{V}$$ and its internal resistance is negligible. The ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and the internal resistance of the voltmeter is $$R_V=1000\,\Omega$$ The readings of the voltmeter and ammeter are respectively:
questions.E: Since the ammeter is ideal (zero internal resistance) we can remove it from the circuit. On the other hand, the voltmeter has an internal resistance, it can be replaced by $$R_V$$. The equivalent resistance between the battery terminals is $$\\ R=R_2+R_{1v}\\$$where $$R_{1V}=\frac{R_1R_V}{R_1+R_V}=\frac{(400\,\Omega)(1000\,\Omega)}{400\,\Omega+1000\,\Omega}=\frac{2000}{7}\,\Omega\\$$The current supplied by the battery is $$\\ I=\frac{E}{R_2+R_{1V}}=\frac{100\,\text{V}}{600\,\Omega+\frac{2000}{7}\,\Omega}=\frac{7}{62}\,\text{A}\\$$The voltmeter reading is $$\\V=R_{1V}I=(\frac{2000}{7}\,\Omega)(\frac{7}{62}\,\text{A})=\frac{1000}{31}\,\text{V}=32\frac{8}{31}\,\text{V}\\$$Applying Ohm's law, the ammeter reading is:$$\\I_1=\frac{V}{R_1}=\frac{\frac{1000}{31}\,\text{V}}{400\,\Omega}=\frac{5}{62}\,\text{A}$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown is used to find the value of $$R$$ based on the ammeter and voltmeter readings which have internal resistances $$r_A$$ and $$R_V$$ respectively. The percentage of relative error in the measurement of $$R$$ is:
questions.E: From the Ohm's law, the voltmeter reading is: $$\\ V=R_Vi_V=R_{RV}i_A\quad \color{red}(1)\color{black}\\$$where $$R_{RV}=\frac{RR_V}{R+R_V}\\$$ From eq(1) $$\\ \frac{1}{R}=\frac{i_A}{V}-\frac{1}{R_V}\\$$but $$R_m=\frac{V}{i_A}$$ is the resistance measured directly from the ammeter and voltmeter readings. $$\\$$Thus from these last two equations $$\\ R_m= \frac{RR_V}{R+R_V}\\$$The percentage of relative error is $$\\ \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{R-R_m}{R}\times 100\\=\frac{R-\frac{RR_V}{R+R_V}}{R}\times 100\\=\frac{R}{R+R_V}\times 100\\$$Thus, for instance $$\\$$If $$R_V=1000\,\Omega$$ and: $$\\$$ a) $$R=10\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{10\,\Omega}{10\,\Omega+1000\,\Omega}\times 100=1\%\\$$ b) $$R=100\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{100\,\Omega}{100\,\Omega+1000\,\Omega}\times 100=10\%\\$$c) $$R=1000\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{1000\,\Omega}{1000\,\Omega+1000\,\Omega}\times 100=50\%\\$$Conclusion: this method is convenient for measuring small resistances, i.e., for $$R_V>>R$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown is used to find the value of $$R$$ based on the ammeter and voltmeter readings which have internal resistances $$r_A$$ and $$R_V$$ respectively. The percentage of relative error in the measurement of $$R$$ is:
questions.E: From the Ohm's law, the currents passing through the voltmeter and ammeter are $$\\ i_V= \frac{E}{R_V} \quad \text{and} \quad i_A=\frac{E}{R+r_A}\quad \color{red}(1)\color{black} \\$$ but $$R_m=\frac{V}{i_A}$$ is the resistance measured directly from the ammeter and voltmeter readings. $$\\$$ Thus from eqs (1) $$\\ R_m= \frac{V}{i_A}= \frac{R_Vi_V}{i_A}= \frac{R_V\frac{E}{R_V}}{\frac{E}{R+r_A}}=R+r_A\\$$The percentage of relative error is $$\\ \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{|R_m-R|}{R}\times 100\\=\frac{|R+r_A-R|}{R}\times 100\\=\frac{r_A}{R}\times 100\\$$Thus, for instance $$\\$$If $$r_A=0.2\,\Omega$$ and: $$\\$$ a) $$R=1\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{0.2\,\Omega}{1\,\Omega}\times 100=20\%\\$$ b) $$R=10\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{0.2\,\Omega}{10\,\Omega}\times 100=2\%\\$$c) $$R=100\,\Omega\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta R}{R}\%=\frac{0.2\,\Omega}{100\,\Omega}\times 100=0.2\%\\$$Conclusion: this method is convenient for measuring large resistances, i.e., for $$R>>r_A$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown is used to raise the temperature of $$480\,\text{g}$$ of water (the specific heat of water is $$c=4186\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{kg K}}$$). The heating element is immersed in the water and has resistance $$R_1=60\,\Omega$$. We will assume that the ammeter has a negligible internal resistance. If $$R_2=30\,\Omega$$, the ammeter reading is $$6\,\text{A}$$ and the circuit is operated during 5 minutes, the temperature of water increases by:
questions.E: Using Kirchhoff's first rule $$\\i=i_1+i_2=\frac{E}{R_1}+\frac{E}{R_2}\Rightarrow E=\frac{R_1R_2}{R_1+R_2}i\\$$ The current $$i_1\\ i_1=\frac{E}{R_1}=\frac{\frac{R_1R_2}{R_1+R_2}i}{R_1}=\frac{R_2}{R_1+R_2}i\\$$ The power dissipated by $$R_1$$ is $$\\P_{R_1}=R_1i_1^2=\frac{R_1R_2^2}{(R_1+R_2)^2}i^2\\$$ This power is used to heat the water. The energy $$Q$$ to raise the temperature of water $$\Delta T$$ is given by $$Q=mc\Delta T\\$$where $$m=480\,\text{g}$$ and $$c=4186\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{kg K}}\\$$Thus, $$\\P_{R_1}=\frac{Q}{\Delta t}\\$$ From these expressions we have $$\\ \Delta T=\frac{R_1R_2^2i^2\Delta t}{(R_1+R_2)^2}\frac{1}{mc}=\frac{(60\,\Omega)(30\,\Omega)^2(6\,\text{A})^2(300\,\text{s})}{(60\,\Omega+30\,\Omega)^2}\frac{1}{(0.480\,\text{kg})(4186\,\text{J/kg K})}=35.8\,^o\text{C}.$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown is used to raise the temperature of $$0.5\,\text{l}$$ of water from $$4\,^o\text{C}$$ to $$100\,^o\text{C}$$ (the specific heat of water is $$c=4186\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{kg K}}$$). The heating element is immersed in the water and has resistance $$R_1$$. We will assume that the ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and that only $$76\%$$ of the energy dissipared by $$R_1$$ is used to heat the water. If $$R_2=10\,\Omega$$, the ammeter reading is $$2\,\text{A}$$, the length of time it takes to do the process is:
questions.E: The current passing trhough $$R_1$$ is $$\\i=\frac{E}{R_1+R_2}\therefore R_1=\frac{E}{i}-R_2\\$$ The  power dissipated by $$R_1$$ is $$P_{R_1}=R_1i^2$$ and the effective power used to heat the water is $$\\P_{eff}=\eta P_{R_1}=\eta R_1i^2\\$$ The energy $$Q$$ to raise the temperature of water $$\Delta T$$ is given by $$Q=mc\Delta T\\$$where $$m=0.5\,\text{kg}$$ and $$c=4186\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{kg K}}$$ and $$\Delta T=100\,^o\text{C}-4\,^o\text{C.}\\$$Thus, $$\\P_{eff}=\frac{Q}{\Delta t}\\$$ From these expressions we have $$\\ \Delta t=\frac{mc\Delta T}{\eta(\frac{E}{i}-R_2)^2}=\frac{(0.5\,\text{kg})(4186\,\frac{\text{J}}{kgK})(96\,^o\text{C})}{0.76(\frac{120\,\text{V}}{2\,\text{A}}-10\,\Omega)(2\,\text{A})^2} \approx 22\,\text{min.}$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown is used to find the specific heat of kerosene contained in a perfect calorimeter. After the current has passed through the resistor for 5 minutes, the kerosene temperature rises by $$5\,^oC$$. We will assume that the ammeter has a negligible internal resistance and that only $$80\%$$ of the energy dissipared by $$R_1$$ is used to heat the kerosene. If the mass of kerosene is $$500\,\text{g}$$, the voltmeter reading is $$V=10.8\,\text{V}$$ and $$E=120\,\text{V}$$, the specific heat of the kerosene is:
questions.E: The power dissipated by $$R_1$$ is $$P_{R_1}=Vi\\$$ The effective power used to heat the kerosene is $$\\P_{eff}=\eta P_{R_1}=\eta Vi\\$$ The energy $$Q$$ to raise the temperature of the rerosene  $$\Delta T$$ is given by $$Q=mc_k\Delta T\\$$where $$m=0.5\,\text{kg}$$ and $$\Delta T=5\,^o\text{C}\\$$Thus, $$\\P_{eff}=\frac{Q}{\Delta t}\\$$ From these expressions we have $$\\ c_k=\frac{\eta Vi \Delta t}{m\Delta T}=\frac{0.8 (10.8\,\text{V})(2\,\text{A})}{(0.5\,\text{kg})(5\,^o\text{C})}=2074\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{kg K}}$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown $$E=120\,\text{V}$$, $$R_2=60\,\Omega$$, $$R_3=30\,\Omega$$ and the ammeter is $$2\,\text{A}$$ If the battery has negligible internal resistance, the power dissipated by $$R_1$$ is
questions.E: From the Kirchhoff's second rule, $$\\V_{ab}=E-R_3i=120\,\text{V}-(30\,\Omega)(2\,\text{A})=60\,\text{V}\\$$ Applying Ohm's law to $$R_2\\ i_2=\frac{V_{ab}}{R_2}=\frac{60\,\text{V}}{60\,\Omega}=1\,\text{A}\\$$ From Kirchhoff's first rule, $$\\ i_{1}=i-i_{2}=2\,\text{A}-1\,\text{A}=1\,\text{A}\\$$Since $$R_1$$ and $$R_2$$ are in parallel, the voltage across them is equal and therefore $$R_1=R_2=60\,\Omega\text{.}\\$$Thus, $$\\ P_{R_1}=R_1i_{R_1}^2=(60\,\Omega)(1\,\text{A})^2\\=60\,\text{W}$$

questions.Q: The circuit shown $$E=100\,\text{V}$$, $$R_1=25\,\Omega$$, $$R_3=78\,\Omega$$, the internal resistance of the battery is $$r=2\,\Omega$$ and the power dissipated by $$R_1$$ is $$16\,\text{W}$$. If the ammeter has negligible resistance, the ammeter reading is:
questions.E: The power dissipated in a resistor with resistance $$R$$ and electric current $$i$$ is $$P=Ri^2\\$$So, the electric current through $$R_1$$ is $$\\ i_1=\sqrt{\frac{P_{R_1}}{R_1}}=\sqrt{\frac{16\,\text{W}}{25\,\Omega}}=\frac{4}{5}\,\text{A}\\$$Applying Kirchhoff's second rule to the left loop, $$E-ri-R_1i_1-R_3i=0\\$$From this equation:$$\\ i=\frac{E-R_1i_1}{R_3+r}=\frac{100\,\text{V}-(25\,\Omega)(\frac{4}{5}\,\text{A})}{78\,\Omega+2\,\Omega}=1\,\text{A}$$
